Don't get me wrong,I loved this movie. It's a beautiful and powerful fictional story, beautifully and powerfully told. Incredible job by everyone involved,and this is a very rich movie,it goes everywhere and never misses,and the control and confidence with which it is driven forward by Darabont reminded me of Coppola. It also reminded me somewhat of The Hill,Pappilon,Brubaker which are one of my favorite films about incarceration.Which brings me to my only discontent about Shawshank Redemption: the fact that Andy Dufresne succeeds in solving everything so completely. Revenge,freedom,happiness,reward for his patience and determination, all with one precise blow. And fate somehow cooperates.Well,that's too much for me.The happy ending was nice,but it was a bit too happy.It really goes straight for that pure part of our being that would want everything to be spectacular and complete, which gives us great emotions but ultimately "insults" our common sense.Andy Dufresne managed to beat the system. It took 18 years but he did it. Beautiful but I don't buy that. Makes for a great movie but doesn't leave much room to meditate.However I wouldn't even think of rating this one less than 9 and really deserves top marks. However,looking around me and thinking about my fate and the fate of others and the fate of the world, I see no Andy Dufresne's. I see the warden, I see Red and I see almost all characters but not Andy.He's like Tristan or Heracles to me,and I don't believe in those hero myths.So,almost perfect movie,but I'll make and take a point by rating it 9.

Most of the movie is great, but i think that the ending was bad. Dufresne telling Red about the field and Zihuatanejo makes it too to figure out that they'll both end up free and happy :) A very dramatic movie until then and with some funny catch lines from time to time. Great acting by not only Tim and Morgan but by most of the actors. The small "stories" besides the main one makes it great, too. The library, Red's tries to get released, the boy who had met the one who committed the crime that Dufresne was sentenced for and such things help the movie going on without making it boring. I also think that it isn't a movie that can be seen a lot of times but i'm not sure before having seen it a couple of times more

I can see why this movie is loved because it is moving and a great emotional experience, however #2 on the IMDb 250. Is this madness? It doesn't deserve to be mentioned in the same sentence as the Godfather. In comparison to the Godfather lets see:1. Is it better directed than the Godfather? Not even nearly close come on this movie didn't even get a nomination while Coppola has directed a masterpiece for all time.2. Is it better Acted than the Godfather? Please Morgan Freedman vs. Brando No question and the Godfather has better supporting actors all around.3. Better Screenplay? That is a joke, Mario Puzo owns it4. Better Music? Forget about the Godfather music is famous.5. So is it all around? not a chanceAs for the movie overall, I did like it but it is good not GREAT. I found it moving and a good film for the triumph of human spirit (its not better than a flew over the cuckoo's nest either) and I found it to be a good movie. On AFI's top 100 list, it was at 72 which is a more appropriate for it. I only compared to the Godfather because the Godfather and Shawshank are in the battle for #1 when its no contest. The ending was a fairy tale too. Yeah sure people always break out of jail with a rock chipper and then move to Mexico with their pal that they met in the joint. Please.

The direction, the acting, the writing, absolutely everything about this film is masterful.To start off with, the acting is excellent.Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman both give what are arguably the performances of their career. Robbins acts with subtlety and understatement, speaking his lines and manipulating his body language with an effortless grace. Freeman's acting and narration are brilliant, in particular his monologue near the end.The direction is some of the best, a surprising and resounding foray into big budget films by Frank Darabont.And of course, the writing is the true shining feature. The creativity of the story, and the twists that give us the ultimate satisfaction are rarities among modern American films.This movie, is unquestionably one of the best films of the 1990s, and perhaps one of the best that has ever been made

I have recently watched The Shawshank Redemption. To put it simply as possible, it is a great piece of movie history.This movie deserves to be where it is (second)on the best Two hundred and fifty greatest films of all time.The Shawshank Redemption is basically about a prisoner, who is in Shawshank prison because of a murder which he didn't commit. The prisoner is a banker called Andy dufresne. As the film shows Andy is a honest man. Andy is also a committed man. Andy is acted by Tim Robbins. Andy Dufresne makes a strong friendship with a man nicknamed Red. Red is acted by Morgan Freeman. I think this movie is on of the best I've ever seen I would rate it 9 out of 10.

I stopped to see Shawshank when I was driving through Cincinnati. The theater was speckled with moviegoers.. all unaware of what an incredible cinematic achievement they were about to witness. There wasn't the slightest sound from the audience....they were mesmerized. The Jail(was in Mansield,Oh./now torn down), the music, the fantastic performances from a slew of great actors, Whitmore as Brooks, Robbins as Andy Dufresne, and Morgan Freeman as Red,..they all did a spectacular job. This is a film(one of the few)...that will leave it's audience in tears of happiness. The narration from Freeman is written with care and this film is crafted and paced with a precision that Hollywood hasn't seen in a long, long, time. "I hope to see the Pacific...I hope it is as blue as it is in my dreams". This film addresses many moral trust issues....from being raped in jail, to finding a friend amongst criminals, to being unjustly incarcerated and then shunned when you prove your innocence.."how could you be so obtuse?".....in the end it is the simplest thing, friendship, that is synonymous with freedom. This was the last time I was in a theater that cheered at the credits....and the only time an audience...so small in numbers...ever did that. One of my top 5 favorite films of all-time. 98/100

I just saw this movie for the first time. My daughter watched it first when she was 12 when it first came out. She went on and on about it saying how great it was then in about 1995. She also loved "Trading Places". I guess the moral of both of these stories is that the good guys win in the end. I now know what she was talking about. It is a great movie, and I can see why it appeals to women.The movie is set in a prison, with the time old tradition of a close friendship over many years of an innocent young man as the hero and an "old lag" who knows all the ropes, in this case Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. This is the same formula earlier used in the films "The Count of Monte Cristo" and "An Innocent Man", both films which are highly recommended, if you liked this one.The film, although made in 1994, goes back to a time when good wins out over evil. unfortunately the fashion for a long time in the nineties movies was for bad to win out, as in "the Terminator" and other movies. The bad guys are as usual the prison boss, The Warder and his Second in Command, the Uniformed Chief Officer. There is a highly unusual twist at the end of the movie, in which the good guys win out. This is a highly improbable situation, but fantasy is allowable in movies. One character of note is that of an old man, played by James Whitmore, who rescues a tiny bird, and nurtures it for years. Thank goodness it doesn't get killed by some other evil person, as usually happens. The old man has to cope with pressures in the outside after he is released.The overarching theme of the movie is one of hope. No matter how bad things get, there is always hope that thing will get better. It also shows that it is possible to have a friendship between black and white people, as the older man, the main character's friend, is a black man. The thing that this movie gave me, is that I can see how wise my daughter already was at 12 years of age, and more importantly, it gives hope and a good philosophy for the rest of my life. I'm sure that it will do the same for those of you who see this movie too.I am unsure as to whether it deserves to be rated the best movie of all time. However movies with hope and goodness as their main themes are generally up there, take "Gone With the Wind", "Schindler's List" and "Lord of the Rings" as examples of this.

The Shawshank Redemption is by far the best movie I've seen in my life. It has it all. The acting is superb and that is not just a complement every single actor that appears in this movie gave probably the best acting that they could give. The story is very rough and hard, being life in prison and all, and yet it's touching, you see the leading character, Andy, never giving up, sticking to his story even when the world seems to turn its back on him. Inside He finds that hope is the only thing that's gonna make him go on, wake up everyday. Very nice message that the movie gives you. Also the way the friendships works, the commitment, the way they stick together and help each other, very beautiful, very beautiful. So great directing, great story, great acting, EXCELLENT MOVIE! Make yourselves a favor and go rent this movie, I promise it won't let you down.

This is in my opinion, tied with Goodfellas for the greatest ever made. Masterfully conceived and directed by Frank Darabont, a powerfully adapted story from Stephen King's short story, amazing acting, and one of the best musical scores ever written made this movie one of the handful of masterpieces that will never die. Along with Goodfellas losing Best Picture, choosing Forest Gump(a great movie) over the Shawshank Redemption was the biggest mistake they ever made. The movie that makes many references to redemption and hope is like Jesus himself. The film did poorly in the box office but has enjoyed one of the greatest afterlives in the history of cinema.Plot: The story is taken from Stephen King's short story "Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption" and Frank Darabont made one of the only movies better than the source material. Masterfully crafted to start with a depressing image of everything the film goes to make one of the most uplifting, happy, and powerful endings in the history of film.Acting: Narrating is Morgan Freeman who gives an Oscar-Worthy performance as Red a lifer for murder in The Shawshank State Prison. Tim Robbins likewise gives a powerful performance as the sympathetic Andy Dufresne a lifer for murder as well. Playing the cold and ruthless Mr. Norton the Warden is Bob Gunton who creates one of the greatest villains I've ever seen on screen.Quality: This film is one of the greatest ever. One of the things that really made this film was probably one of the best, most uplifting and powerful musical scores I've ever heard which also deserved an Oscar. The camera work was also fantastic opening with a sky-view of the prison.This is one of the few movies where if you don't see the genius of it I will have to question if you really seen the entire film or any of the film. This is along with Goodfellas the greatest movies ever. There are only a handful of masterpieces in history and this is one of them. Even less is the amount of films that will never die and will always stand the test of time. This is one of them. This is a film that you should just buy.11/10

The film tells the story of Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), an educated banker sentenced to life for the murder of his wife and her lover. In prison, Andy inspires his fellow inmates with his courage and humanity and has a profound effect on Red (Morgan Freeman), an older prisoner, who has given up hope.Unlike many films of the 90's, "The Shawshank Redemption" has "high concept" plot premise and is somewhat episodic compared with the tight, linear narratives of closer structured pictures. This sense of freedom in the storytelling allows the film to consistently throw up genuine surprises, as the viewer isn't constantly on guard for clues and plot points. In hindsight, we tend to forget how successfully director Frank Darabont leads us to expect a very different resolution."The Shawshank Redemption" does things well that you might not expect. It has lengthy voice-overs (that actually work well) and it has a sappy predictable ending, but yet these elements work because they are not placed in the over-used, meaningless context that movies today place them in. The voice overs are also consistently used in such a way that distinct worlds are created. There's a real world inside the prison and the surreal outside world.These two distinct worlds are created help to place the viewer inside the halls of the prison, they are no longer watching a movie, but they are also feeling it.This is a movie that will remain a favorite of the people for many decades to come. 10/10

The greatness of "The Shawshank Redemption" is all the great values this film is built on - love, friendship, lending hand to another man. What is also wonderful about this film is its combination of its serious moments with the beautiful humour. In addition, the film has a third-person narrator which adds a lot of meaning to it and allows to develop a closer relationship with Red and - through Red - with Andy. As for Stephen King's story that the film is based on, it a bit disappointed me. However, after reading it I appreciated Frank Darabont's work even more - I saw how much imagination and creativity he had to use for "The Shawshank Redemption". Lastly, the score is so beautiful you can cry at moments, e.g. the piece accompanying the arrival of Andy's transport to the Shawshank Prison. I guess I watched this movie five times and think I will watch it many times more. I recommend it to everyone.

*The Shawshank SPOILERS* In the early '20s, Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), a quiet bank employee, is arrested, tried and sentenced to life in prison for the murders of his wife and her lover, murders that he didn't commit.The calm man has to rough up really soon, in order to survive life in the Shawshank prison, but manages to develop a friendship with a fellow inmate called Red (Morgan Freeman) and to be employed in the contability office by the corrupt director of Shawshank, thus helping his escape plan...When I first watched this movie, a few years ago, I was so in awe that as soon as I got out of school (where me and my classmates watched it during a morning without teachers) I went and bought it.It's an instant classic, an inspiring movie, based upon a short story by Stephen King (!), marvelously written, acted and directed, and fully deserving of being owned.The Shawshank Redemption: 10/10.

I am totally puzzled as to why this film is so highly rated. It is reasonably well made, has a very good cast, and it held my interest. However, it has nothing new in it. It wasn't fun. It wasn't life changing. It didn't make me want to be a better person. None of the characters in the film were particularly appealing. The protagonist's method for escaping from prison was obviously not new, since he flashed his copy of "The Count of Monte Christo." There was an unusual directness in confronting gay rape in prison, but I find it to be not that compelling a subject. I guess that leaves redemption. To me, he paid way too high a price for thinking about, but not actually, killing his wife. After she cheated on him. Perhaps the point was that he felt so guilty about her death, he wanted to be punished. By spending twenty years getting raped in prison? That's not punishment, it's just sick.

This is definitely the best film I've ever seen.Ever What pulled me in is how much you start to feel for these characters as if their real people. Another thing that I liked is how the characters change for example Andy(main character) at the start hes a healthy looking man and after 20 years he has grey hairs bags under his eyes and a broken spirit.In the end you don't care what happens to the warden you don't care if he becomes president as long as Andy escapes.In truth this is a love story but not a regular love story this is A story of two of the most unlikely candidates.There's Andy a hardworking lawyer and then there's red sent to prison at the age of 18 for murder and armed robbery two polar opposites but in the end they might as well be family.This is the single most powerful movie ever at the end I was crying something that has never happened before anyway this is a film to see before you die words cant honestly explain how great this film is you have to see it.

I do think some films get better the more you view them. "Shawshank" is such a film. Whever I stumble across it on a cable channel, I am simply unable to break away from it, even though I've seen it a dozen times. The best films are "simple stories, well told." From the script, to the acting, to the direction, to the sets, and - most importantly - in its message, "The Shawshank Redemption" is absolutely first-rate. It's always fun to see a wronged man win in the end, but in this story it is the manner in which Andy prevails that is so gripping. The scene in which Tim Robbins as Andy ponders if he is in some way responsible for his fate because of his thoughts is amazing. And Morgan Freeman's greatest film moment comes when he faces the parole board one more time. Most movies blow from your mind minutes after the final credits, this one stays with you forever. I'm ready to see it again.

*spoilers*The first time I saw "The Shawshank Redemption",I was simply blown away by how powerful this movie is. There are no action sequences or romances, but the subtle drama of a man who is wrongly accused is easily identifiable, possibly because we realize that it could happen to anyone. What makes the main character (Andy Dufrene) find the strength to survive his term of life in prison is his knowledge of his innocence, and his friendship with Red, a convicted murderer, who is slowly reforming throughout the movie. The end of the movie is perhaps one of the most uplifting scenes I have ever watched, as justice finally prevails, due to Andy's determination and careful planning.I never get tired of this movie. From the beginning of the movie where Andy considers murder, to his incarceration for that same murder(ironically committed by someone else), and his long stay in prison under a cruel warden, and finally the best-ever use of a Raquel Welch art poster. Ever.I highly encourage this movie to anyone who hasn't seen it. It is a classic, and the acting is superb. Even smallest roles are memorable.

A heartbreaking story fraught with Passion, Loss, A Dream, and Friendship. There's only so much i can say about a film that is loved by millions and yet misunderstood by more. It's the visual version of a musical ballad. A soft and thoughtful piece and yet created by a hard centre and churned by the brilliant hands of Frank Darabont and the great acting of both Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. A True Classic."Andy Dufresne, is sent to Shawshank Prison for the murder of his wife and secret lover. He is very isolated and lonely at first, but realises there is something deep inside your body, that people can't touch and get to....'HOPE'. Andy becomes friends with prison 'fixer' Red (Morgan Freeman), and Andy epitomises why it is crucial to have dreams. His spirit and determination, leads us into a world full of imagination, filled with courage and desire. Will Andy ever realise his dreams...?"

This film really got me. As soon as Morgan Freeman got into the movie, I started to get interested and the film ended up to be a crowd cheer and a tearjerker. The story is so well done. This movie is based on Stephen Kings short novel "Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption."Vice president of the Portland bank Andy Dufrane (Tim Robbins) goes to jail for two life sentences he did not commit. When he goes to jail, the first step onto the prison ground will change his life. When he's been beaten around by the queer bull Diamond brothers, he decides to wait a few years to escape. Before these years he decides to meet the institutionalized prisoner Red (Morgan Freeman) who can get Andy or other prisoners whatever they wanted. He can get you packs of cigarettes, jack hammers, naked lady cards, and posters of Rita Hayworth, Marilyn Monroe etc. Andy wanted a jack hammer to crack his wall. Red promised Andy that if the guards find his hammer, they will never do business again. Andy never got caught and Red and him both became friends for a long time. Andy became a big hit for the prisoners and the guards when he helped them with their tax problems. In exchange he got the prisoners beers. After he got the prison library to expand. That is most of what I can say about 'The Shawshank Redemption.'Why did this film not win any academy awards? I felt this film was a lot better than the brutally charged 'Pulp Fiction' than Tom Hanks life achievements as 'Forrest Gump.' This picture sees life more beautifully and more possible. This is a great luminous character study of fortitude and friendship behind bars at its finest.

I saw this movie at the end of a particularly bad and miserable day in my life and it is safe to say that I was not particularly looking forward to this one.Two and a half hours later I was on my feet again and was once more prepared to look the world in the eyes. Such is the power of this movie.Tim Robbins plays a sincere man who is sent to to jail for a crime he did not commit. Inside, he meets extraordinary human beings, all of who you will fall in love with within minutes of meeting them. Chief among these is the character of Red, played by none other than the legendary Morgan Freeman.Together with Andy and Red you learn about life and friendship and the evils inherent in human nature. You laugh with them, are sad with them and feel their pain, and in the end, when the two friends meet again on a remote beach years later, you finally break down and cry with them.This movie is emotionally powerful and reminds us once again what the movies should be.It is not sentimental in any way, and that is a rarity these days. And if you do not feel sad, and your heart does not beat faster with Morgan Freeman's soliloquoy at the end, you cannot call yourself human. For, then, you have missed one of the greatests gifts one can receive: a passion for life.

Best movie ever made. From the beginning to the end this movie is so perfect it's hard to put it into words, every little detail is stunning. Maybe my opinion is not the most objective because this has been my favorite movie for quite some time, but however, I remembered the first time I saw it. I could't get it of my mind for a couple of days. And still, after seeing it over 20 times, I often think about it and smile. The part when Andy escapes and the next 30 minutes after that you can't stop smiling, it's so perfect. The biggest star must go to Morgan Freeman who gives this movie even more deep and feeling. To everyone who haven't seen it yet, do it, you will not regret it.

This for me is the best movie of all time because it shows companionship through out the movie between the two main characters (andy and red). It's true to life with the little details of when it was set and the story was genius, great twist at the end when he reveals the hole in the wall, great stuff, your rooting for Andy the whole time as we all know he is innocent. He gets his revenge in the end by out smarting the person who over looks the prison, which for me is the best part of the movie. The three sister also shine a light on how desperate in mates can get, and Red shows the craft of an experienced prisoner smuggling small goods for the rest, he takes Andy under his wing and tells him moral after moral. Great movie, i can watch it over and over again, which, normally i cant with most long movies, but this is one movie that is something that little extra special. Watch it!!!!

***SPOILERS***This is a great movie that shows us that hope is a great thing. The story tells us about Andy Dufrense, a man who is falsely accused for killing his wife and her lover and who gets sent to Maines strongest prison. Shawshank. In Shawshank Andy gets new friends, as well as enemies. Being the wise man that he is, he begins to inject wisdom in people. Helping them. He also meets Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding. A man also accused for murder, but on true accusations. They become great friends and together they give themselves hope. This is a wonderful movie that leaves you happy and shaken. Its an must see.

I read this novella in Stephen Kings "Four Seasons" while i was doing my GCSE exams. i remember then what a profound effect the story had on me. A story of hope through extreme adversity and the power of friendship that i thought could not be found between two men. The sheer anticipation of this film being released was almost heart stopping, but coupled with the fear it would not live up to my expectations. i also remember thinking that i did not want to see it for fear of it shattering my own perceptions of the two main characters, ANDY and RED. i need not have feared a thing.....the screenplay and adaptation was done with nothing short of pure brilliance. the camera work and choice of location could not have been more suitable. perhaps it is a symbol of how well Mr King writes that, it seems, everyones picture of everything is the same!!! Thus is was quite easy to choose sets, locations and of course actors. In the book, RED is a white, Irish man......against all odds, i cannot imagine ANYONE else delivering such a captivating, believable and utterly brilliant performance as Morgan Freeman. This man deserves 20 Oscars his acting together with the small stabs of narration are mind blowing who else could have done this?!! NO-ONE!! Tim Robbins IS ANDY!....his whole movement and attitude were exactly what King had written, this was encompassed in Robbins' portrayal perfectly. together the chemistry they had was beautiful, you could see that these characters were good friends, as well as the actors that played them. The visionary pieces of the film that will always linger? well the whole film lingers, such was the effect it had on me, but the two specific points in the film? Firstly, Andy described to RED where he could find a box, near a tree in a field, under some rocks to be exact. Now this bit is in the book (obviously!!) but i remember when i read it, the picture of that tree, in that field, next to that wall. In the film it was as if they had asked ME to choose the location, a chill went down my spine and it nearly brought me to tears!!! and i am NOT KIDDING!!!!. The second bit, well its right at the end, its the smile on RED's face when he sees ANDY again. This is not a feeble lip turning grin.....NO this is a full , both sets of teeth, cheek aching smile!!!! it IS the biggest and most emotional smile i have ever seen in any film. i could go on for pages about this film, i have been a film fan ever since i can remember, sitting with my father on a Sunday afternoon (before the times of VCR's or satellite, when you watched what was on that day or tough!!!) we watched films like "The African Queen", "Bridge on the River Kwai", "Citizen Kane", "The Rear Window", etc and from then i always liked a good film with a good story, The Shawshank Redemption was already a good story, it took genius to make it a GREAT film. to date i have seen it over 100 times. this has taken me through 3 copies on Video before the DVD came out, i am now on my 2nd DVD. if i have to buy another 100 DVD's it will always always alway be my number one favourite film of all time. It is a film you can watch at any time, when you are in any mood and it is still as compelling as the first time i saw it, or indeed the first time i read the story. 20 out of 10........

In the 11 years since the release and realization of the brilliance of this film, I'm sure many, many legions of people have written reviews that summarily praise (and viscously, ignorantly degrade - you know who you are, those whose reviews appear under the "hated" tag on the reviews pages) and criticize the movie. I can't add anything that hasn't been said before, except just say how much this movie affected me and how much I love it. Tim Robbins, always a great actor, and always very, very human. Morgan Freeman, c'mon, who da man? Who da MAN?!?!? HE DA MAN!!! He DA MAN!!! He DA smooth-walkin', smoother-talking', illest muthaf***in' epitome of "cool". And not a bad actor, either, heh heh (yes, I know I am drastically understating that fact). The direction - flawless. Every shot, every camera angle, every color tone (plus the quality of the film and the cameras themselves) embody such finesse, such power. Humanity! That's what the word I was looking for, the word that describes what every frame overwhelmingly emanates, even during the "brutal" scenes (I put "brutal" in quotes because I unfortunately have seen plenty of sick s@%* in my life and am now sadly desensitized to movie violence; violence on the news and in real life though, DAMN I get sickened and angered at perpetrators). The very human friendship twixt the leads are very well handled, never turning into cutesy schmaltz or soap-y melodrama. The writing. Yes, I know. "How the hell does his cell open up into a pipe drain? That's horrible plot!!!!!!" Ask yourselves: If his cell wall didn't open up over the pipe, would he have escaped? Would the story have been the same AT ALL if his cell opened up anywhere else other than that river of s@%*? And then think about Andy. Would someone of his intelligence would have discontinued his digging and succumbed to madness if what he saw when he looked through the initial tiny hole on the other side was anything other than a road to freedom? Convenient plot twist? Sure! But not outlandish. It could happen (not like a New York Cop winning a $4M lottery ticket and tipping a waitress half, no matter how much he wanted to get with her). Very good storytelling and very tight screen writing. This movie is great. Plain and simple. It did confirm one thing in general to me, though, especially in these times of moral conflict that is dividing the "greatest nation on the face of the earth" bitterly: Those who thump the bible the hardest, usually cling to it the hardest out of fear and out of guilt. Love this film.

This is simply a film that you would struggle to find a flaw with. The performances are wonderful, the story is involving and deep, the characters are likable and understandable, and the whole climax to the story is satisfying and rewards you for having stayed the course. It's funny, it's moving, and it presents an incredible perception on the ideas of hope, freedom and the vibrancy of the human spirit.If you haven't seen this film yet, then go out, rent a copy, and watch it. If you have a friend who hasn't seen it either, then invite them round - believe me, they'll thank you for it. This is one film that really is a must-see.

Another non-award winning movie that is consider one of the best movies ever made I loved this movie and can watch it over all the time Should have one best picture not just one brilliant but two brilliant performances by both Tim and Morgan this movie is great can,t say that enough but ill hold off if you haven't seen this movie your not a movie lover you don't know what your missing kind of like the fugitive in a sense but better another wrongly convicted person and treated horrible in prison pulls off a brilliant exit and learns a few things while in the pen underrated at the time now its rated under a movie it should be above a must watch movie.

After seeing The Shawshank Redemption on television, I knew I had to see the whole film. It was incredible. After that I decided to read the book, and this is one of the rare times that a film outdid the book it was based off of. Even though the ending of the book was the same (poster, escape), the film just had a certain something to it that made it amazing. Very good movie that tells a good story.Life in early 1900's prison builds some strong friendships among the inmates. Daily prison existence takes its toll on you so you do what you have to in order to make it through. Inmates learn how to make the corruption work in their favor and take full advantage of it by building on the trust the guards have in the inmates.I don't think they could have come up with a better ending to the story than what they did. This movie is a masterpiece that you will find yourself watching any time you are in the mood for a good movie.Highly recommended film. Watch it, you will be pleased.

The only way to summarize The Shawhank Redemption is with one word Incredible. This movie is beautifully told and magically shown on the screen. It will bring a tear to your eye and fill you with hope. Andy Dufresne is convicted murderer. He has to spend two life terms in Shawshank state prison. There he gets brutally gang raped and meets many friends including Red the guy who can get things. If you have never seen this movie then you must be crazy. I strongly advice you to see this movie especially if you are having hard times this will make you feel and think so much better. You have to see this movie!!!
